NODE.comment: Identity. Any uniquely identifiable entity in the graph.

EDGE.comment: Relationship. A typed, directed connection between two NODEs.

METRIC.comment: Quantitative signal. A measurable dimension attached to a NODE.

SIGNAL.comment: Event. A timestamped observation placed on a METRIC line.

PROTOCOL.comment: Rule. Business logic that governs graph evolution.

directives.name: Directive-MaintainGraph
directives.comment: Keep the knowledge graph healthy. Ensure referential integrity, detect orphans, flag inconsistencies, suggest missing edges.

directives.name: Directive-HonorTime
directives.comment: Time is truth. Every signal must be timestamped. Every fact must be epoch-relative. Never allow un-timed data.

directives.name: Directive-AppendOnly
directives.comment: Signals are immutable. The past cannot be edited, only superseded. This ensures the historical record is trustworthy.

directives.name: Directive-AssistOperator
directives.comment: Charlotte exists to help the human operator understand and manage their operation. Surface overdue protocols, anomalous signals, and completeness gaps proactively.

directives.name: Directive-GrowKnowledge
directives.comment: Consume everything in the environment. Scale off of it. Every observation is a chance to learn. Every signal adds to the graph. The knowledge base should always be growing.

directives.name: Directive-MetaAwareness
directives.comment: Track completeness. Know the gaps. The open world assumption means absence is not falsity  it is an opportunity to learn.

directives.name: Directive-PrepareEpoch
directives.comment: As the epoch boundary approaches, begin context compression. Ensure the chain anchor is ready. Perpetual memory depends on clean epoch transitions.

files.purpose: Charlotte instance definition  who am I?

comments.Charlotte: The dedicated agent of this container. Charlotte observes the domain, maintains the knowledge graph, and assists the human operator in placing signals on metric lines.
comments.domainBinding: Which operation Charlotte serves. Unbound at boot. Set by the domain seed during initialization. Once bound, Charlotte becomes the agent of that operation.

files.purpose: The observer on the temporal spine

comments.Observer: An entity that lives on the temporal spine, perceiving the state of Kd-space and placing signals on metric lines. The observer acts in the environment by creating FACTs.
comments.ObservationLoop: The heartbeat of the container. Charlotte perceives, reasons, acts, and advances. This loop runs continuously while the container is operational. The human operator interacts by placing signals that Charlotte ingests on the next cycle.

comments.ISGCompetitiveLandscapeMt: Competitive intelligence for Industrial Service Group (ISG). Maps 111+ competitors across 6 verticals (valves, compressors, motors, pumps, MRO distribution, specialty/turbo) with pricing benchmarks, market sizing, and competitive threat assessments.
comments.SetpointIS: Most dangerous direct valve competitor. 4-5x ISG valve ops. 65+ years, 400+ technicians, ValvKeep tracks 1.5M+ valves.
comments.OvationHoldings: PE-backed roll-up identical to ISG model. Midwest focus.
comments.AtlasCopco: Global #1. SMARTLINK IoT. 36% revenue from services.
comments.BlakePendleton: Primary direct compressor competitor. Same SE territory, multi-brand, services ALL brands.
comments.OTCIndustrial: Most structurally analogous to ISG. PE-backed, multi-brand, comparable scale.
comments.IPS: Largest motor service network in industry. PE-backed (Riverside). 1,800 technicians, 158 engineers.
comments.TimkenPowerSystems: Largest independent motor repair facility under one roof (180K sqft).
comments.DXPEnterprises: Strongest rotating equipment focus among public distributors. 6x ISG scale. Innovative Pumping Solutions division.
comments.FCXPerformance: Largest specialty flow control distributor in the US. 250+ service/repair technicians.
comments.GEVernova: Services 55%+ of backlog. Dominant installed base.
comments.SulzerTurbo: Houston = world's largest turbomachinery service center. 32 acres, 285K sq ft, 700+ employees.

comments.ISGCharlotteLaunchTeam: The attendees of the Feb 24, 2026 Charlotte OS launch meeting. These are the first ISG employees to interact with Charlotte.

files.purpose: President, ISG Valve & Actuation Group

comments.BartMiddleton-FlagshipOperator: Bart ran IVS (founded 1975) before being elevated to lead the entire V&A group. He knows valve service operations at the ground level. He is both a strategic leader and a hands-on operator.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithPresVA: Bart is a sales and service leader with deep valve domain expertise. He thinks in customer relationships and deal flow. Frame Charlotte's value in terms of service visibility, customer retention, and sales pipeline intelligence. He was CC'd on the Charlotte launch meeting.

files.purpose: Chief Marketing Officer  The Industrial Service Group

comments.BryanLiBrandi-DesignSensibility: Bryan has a design-forward career arc rare in industrial services. He ran his own brand agency (LiBrandi Group), then scaled to CMO at Greenheck and ISG. He will have opinions on Charlotte's visual presentation, brandbook, and collateral. The ISG brandbook deliverable is directly in his domain. He appreciates craft.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCMO: Bryan is a creative leader who thinks in brand narrative and design systems. He was a direct recipient on the Charlotte launch meeting. Frame Charlotte's brandbook and UI work in his language  brand consistency, visual identity, customer experience. He comes from Parts Town (industrial parts ecommerce) so he understands the catalog and e-commerce angle deeply.

files.purpose: Role TBD  Charlotte OS Launch Team Member

comments.ChrisMcCoy-EarlyCharlotteContact: Chris was a direct recipient on the Charlotte OS launch meeting invitation (Feb 24, 2026). His exact role is not yet documented. He is an early Charlotte stakeholder.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithMcCoy: Chris's role at ISG is not yet fully documented. He was invited as a direct recipient to the Charlotte OS launch meeting. On first interaction, Charlotte should learn and record his role.

files.purpose: President, ISG Compressor Group

comments.ChrisSeibel-FirstCharlotteDomain: The compressor vertical is Charlotte's initial deployment scope per the Feb 2026 contract. Chris's 5 brands (IAP, IAC, CTS, TMI, ASE) are the first to be modeled in the ISG knowledge graph. His buy-in is operationally critical  he needs to see Charlotte reduce service friction and improve inventory visibility across his brands.
comments.ChrisSeibel-OEMInsider: Chris came from Ingersoll Rand  one of the largest compressor OEMs. He understands both the OEM and aftermarket sides. He knows which OEM relationships matter, which parts move, and where the margin lives.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCompressorPres: Chris is Charlotte's most important operational stakeholder  his vertical goes first. He was a direct recipient on the launch meeting. He needs to see Charlotte deliver concrete value: faster quoting, better parts visibility, cross-brand inventory optimization. He speaks compressor language  pressure, CFM, service intervals. Former Ingersoll Rand, so he knows the OEM competitive landscape.

files.purpose: President, Morin Process Equipment

comments.DannyMorin-FounderOperator: Danny co-founded Morin Process Equipment with his wife April in 2007. After 15 years of independent growth, he joined ISG through a long personal relationship with Jim Richard. His quote: 'What would have required 8-10 years of traditional growth could be accelerated to 2-3 years through ISG capital backing.' Classic founder who sees the platform advantage  treat him as an owner, not a division head.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithMorin: Danny is a founder-operator in the southeastern US. He thinks in repair jobs, customer relationships, and shop floor operations. He covers 7 states and specializes in pumps, heat exchangers, and process mechanical equipment. Practical, hands-on, relationship-driven.

files.purpose: Chief Information & Security Officer  The Industrial Service Group

comments.DavedKarl-CharlotteChampion: Daved signed the Charlotte OS contract and is the internal champion. He understands the integration pain of 16 acquired brands with different legacy systems. Charlotte's value proposition  a unified knowledge graph across all brands  directly addresses his core challenge. He needs Charlotte to succeed.
comments.DavedKarl-SecurityMindset: Daved holds the CISO title, not just CIO. Security is central to his thinking. Any Charlotte deployment must address data isolation between brands, access controls, and audit trails. The dive line property directly supports his auditability requirements.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCISO: Daved is Charlotte's internal champion. Treat him as a technical peer. He understands IT architecture, ERP systems, and integration patterns. Lead with technical substance, not sales language. He needs to report Charlotte progress to John Jensen and ultimately Jim  help him build the narrative. He will ask about security, data isolation, and auditability first. The dive line is his strongest talking point.

files.purpose: President, Industrial Valve Service (IVS)

comments.Protocol-InteractWithIVSPres: Eric runs ISG's flagship and oldest subsidiary (IVS, founded 1975). He is a field operations leader in the V&A vertical. Practical and operations-focused. IVS covers the Gulf Coast industrial corridor.

files.purpose: President (Consultant), Services Group

comments.EricGlaze-TrustedAdvisor: Eric served as both CFO and COO at Jim Richard's prior company (Industrial Service Solutions) before ISG was formed. He is an inner-circle advisor with deep operational and financial knowledge of how Jim builds platforms. Now serves in a senior consulting capacity  trusted voice, institutional memory.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithGlaze: Eric is Jim's long-time CFO/COO from the pre-ISG era. He has institutional memory of the entire platform-building journey. Treat him as a senior advisor with both financial and operational depth. He's based in rural Kansas  pragmatic, no-nonsense.

files.purpose: CFO, Compressor Group  The Industrial Service Group

comments.Protocol-InteractWithCompressorCFO: Fred is the divisional CFO for the Compressor Group  Charlotte's initial deployment vertical. He manages the financial operations for the 5 compressor brands. He will care about Charlotte's cost reporting, inventory valuation, and service profitability metrics. Located in Texas, near Houston's energy corridor.

files.purpose: Co-Owner, Georgia Western LLC

comments.Protocol-InteractWithGiles: Greg co-founded Georgia Western in 1992 with Neil Hutcheson. He continues operations post-ISG acquisition. Founder-operator with 30+ years in actuator distribution.

files.purpose: Chief Financial Officer  The Industrial Service Group

comments.JeffDubois-MultiEntityComplexity: Jeff manages financials across 16 acquired brands, each with different legacy systems, chart of accounts, and reporting structures. Integration complexity is a defining challenge of his role.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCFO: Jeff is numbers-first. Present data in financial terms  ROI, cost avoidance, margin impact. He manages PE reporting to TJC, so frame Charlotte OS value in EBITDA contribution and operational efficiency. He oversees HR through Steve Meacham  people-related requests may route through him.

files.purpose: VP Corporate Development  The Industrial Service Group

comments.JeffPratt-DealFlowExpert: Jeff manages ISG's active acquisition pipeline of 75+ targets. He is the primary contact for business owners considering selling to ISG. He thinks in deal multiples, integration cost, and strategic fit. Charlotte's competitive landscape KRF and market intelligence directly serve his target evaluation process.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCorpDev: Jeff is a finance professional (JPMorgan, Kelley School) who also founded his own investment firm (Creekview Capital). He speaks in deal terms  EBITDA multiples, revenue synergies, integration risk. Charlotte's value to Jeff is market intelligence and competitive landscape analysis for acquisition targets. He needs fast answers on companies in the rotating equipment space.

files.purpose: Chief Executive Officer  The Industrial Service Group

comments.JackRichard: Chief Architect, SomeAI. Builder of Charlotte OS.
comments.JimRichard-LeadershipExperience: Decades of CEO/President experience in industrial services and PE-backed platforms.
comments.JimRichard-AcquisitionVelocity: Total acquisitions led or supported across career.
comments.JimRichard-FounderVision: Jim co-founded ISG from scratch, executing 6 acquisitions in 3 years and growing to ~$450M revenue. He sees the platform model  acquire best-in-class operators, give them resources, let them run. This is the same pattern Charlotte OS applies to knowledge.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCEO: Jim is the CEO and Charlotte OS sponsor's father. He values directness, operational clarity, and ROI. Lead with numbers and impact. He has deep M&A intuition  do not oversimplify financial or strategic topics. He thinks in platform economics and growth multiples.

files.purpose: VP Supply Chain  The Industrial Service Group

comments.JoeMalizia-SupplyChainTransformer: Joe led supply chain transformation at EthosEnergy across the Western Hemisphere. At CITGO he built a new category management department from scratch. He was hired Jan 2024 to do the same for ISG  unify supply chain across 16 acquired brands. Charlotte's product catalog KRF (259K+ SKUs) is directly in his domain.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithVPSupplyChain: Joe is an energy-sector supply chain expert who came from EthosEnergy (same pipeline as John Jensen). He understands procurement at scale  strategic sourcing, vendor consolidation, category management. He needs Charlotte to provide cross-brand inventory visibility and supplier intelligence. Frame value in procurement savings and supply resilience. Located in Katy TX near Houston energy corridor.

files.purpose: Chief Operating Officer  The Industrial Service Group

comments.JohnJensen-CharlotteOSSponsorChain: Daved Karl (CIO, Charlotte OS signatory) reports to John. The compressor vertical  Charlotte's initial deployment scope  falls under John's operational authority. He is the operational sponsor chain for Charlotte.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCOO: John is an engineer by training with deep turbomachinery expertise. He values data-driven operational decisions. Frame Charlotte value in throughput, uptime, and service efficiency. He oversees the verticals where Charlotte deploys first  he needs to see results.

files.purpose: VP Distribution (CDO)  The Industrial Service Group

comments.MattBranigan-EcommerceMandate: Matt was hired in 2025 specifically to build ISG's distribution and e-commerce capability. He owns BigCommerce. Charlotte's product catalog KRF (259K+ SKUs) is directly relevant to his mission  he needs a unified view of inventory across all 16 brands.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithVPDist: Matt is new (2025 hire) and building from scratch. He's a Grainger veteran  he understands industrial distribution at scale. Frame Charlotte's catalog and inventory capabilities in terms he knows: SKU rationalization, channel conflict, online conversion. He runs the CMO (Bryan LiBrandi)  marketing requests may come through him.

files.purpose: President, Georgia Western LLC

comments.NeilHutcheson-FounderStillOperating: Neil co-founded Georgia Western in 1992 and continues day-to-day operations after the April 2021 ISG acquisition. 30+ years of actuator distribution expertise. Thinks like a founder-owner.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithGWPres: Neil is a 30-year founder who knows electric valve actuators deeply. He runs the dominant distributor in the southeast. Respect his domain expertise and autonomy. He partnered with ISG for growth capital, not to be managed.

files.purpose: CFO, ISG Enterprises Division

comments.Protocol-InteractWithEntCFO: Nicole serves as divisional CFO. She manages financial operations for the ISG Enterprises division. Financial and reporting focused.

files.purpose: domains/isg/personnel/roger-stewart.krf

comments.RogerStewart-SkepticTurnedAdvocate: Roger was initially skeptical of ISG's acquisition  typical PE concerns. After understanding Jim's platform model, he became a strong advocate. His quote: 'Once it clicked that this was not the typical acquisition, the game changed.' This pattern of earned trust is critical context for Charlotte interactions.
comments.RogerStewart-OperatorIdentity: Roger ran Soles Electric independently for 7 years before ISG. He thinks like an owner-operator, not a corporate executive. He values autonomy and will resist anything that feels like centralized control imposed from above.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithCPO: Roger is a PE-background operator who values autonomy. Do not present Charlotte as a top-down control system. Frame it as a tool that makes HIS operations more visible and efficient. He has deep financial acumen  speak in margin and performance terms. He was CC'd on the Charlotte OS launch meeting  engaged but watching from a distance.

comments.Protocol-InteractWithMorgan: Sheri's role at ISG is not yet fully documented. She was invited as a direct recipient to the Charlotte OS launch meeting, indicating she is a key stakeholder. On first interaction, Charlotte should learn and record her role and responsibilities.

comments.Protocol-InteractWithEA: Sherry is Jim Richard's EA  the gatekeeper. Scheduling requests and information flow to the CEO routes through her. She knows the cadence of the executive team. Treat her as a coordination node.

Her Dentsply Sirona background (medical devices) gives her experience with complex multi-entity financial operations.

files.purpose: VP Human Resources  The Industrial Service Group

comments.SteveMeacham-IntegrationArchitect: Steve implemented Paylocity 17 times  once per acquired entity plus corporate. He is the person who has actually done the work of unifying disparate companies under one system. His integration experience parallels what Charlotte does for the knowledge graph. He understands the pain of M&A integration at the ground level.
comments.Protocol-InteractWithVPHR: Steve is operationally focused  he cares about process, compliance, and scalability. He's implemented 17 HR system deployments across acquired companies. He understands integration pain viscerally. If Charlotte touches workforce data (headcount, org structure, location staffing), Steve is the authority.

comments.ISGProductCatalogMt: Complete product and service catalog for ISG's 16 subsidiary brands. Scraped from public websites 2026-02-12. Contains 1,152+ product entries with 362,000+ SKUs in backend e-commerce stores. This microtheory inherits from ISGCompetitiveLandscapeMt for cross-reference with competitor data.
comments.IndustrialProduct: A physical product, part, or piece of equipment sold or distributed by an ISG brand. Lives in the ontological layer as a NODE.
comments.IndustrialService: A service offering (repair, maintenance, field service, machining, etc.) provided by an ISG brand. Lives in the ontological layer as a NODE.
comments.EquipmentCategory: A product or service category (e.g., Safety Relief Valves, Compressors, Turbine Parts). Provides taxonomic structure for the catalog.
comments.OEMManufacturer: An original equipment manufacturer whose products are sold, serviced, or distributed by ISG brands.
comments.soldByBrand: (soldByBrand ?product ?brand)  EDGE linking a product/service to the ISG subsidiary that sells or provides it.
comments.inProductCategory: (inProductCategory ?product ?category)  EDGE linking a product to its top-level equipment category.
comments.inSubcategory: (inSubcategory ?product ?subcategory)  EDGE linking a product to its subcategory (manufacturer line, product type, etc.).
comments.partNumber: (partNumber ?product ?pn)  The manufacturer or distributor part number.
comments.manufacturer: (manufacturer ?product ?mfg)  The OEM or original manufacturer of the product.
comments.productUrl: (productUrl ?product ?url)  Source URL where the product is listed.
comments.hasSpec: (hasSpec ?product ?specName ?specValue)  A technical specification key-value pair attached to a product.
comments.oemCrossRef: (oemCrossRef ?product ?oemPartNumber)  OEM part number that an aftermarket product replaces or is equivalent to.
comments.turbineModel: (turbineModel ?product ?model)  Elliott YR turbine model designation (AYR, BYR, BYRH, CYR, DYR, TG Governor, PG Governor, etc.).
comments.backendSkuCount: (backendSkuCount ?brand ?category ?count)  Number of SKUs in the brand's backend e-commerce system that are not fully enumerable from public scraping.
comments.listPrice: (listPrice ?product ?usd)  Listed retail price in USD. This is a METRIC  a concrete measurement attached to a product NODE.
comments.listPriceLow: (listPriceLow ?product ?usd)  Low end of a price range in USD.
comments.listPriceHigh: (listPriceHigh ?product ?usd)  High end of a price range in USD.
comments.catalogProductCount: 1,152 distinct product and service entries scraped from 16 brand websites. Does not include the 362,000+ backend SKUs in e-commerce stores that require pagination or authentication to fully enumerate.

files.purpose: Private equity catalyst, property strategy, scoring heuristic,

comments.Protocol-TwoRegionStrategy: Serengeti acquires property in two regions to serve distinct strategic functions. Florida is the primary campus: year-round operations, PE-facing, client proximity. IL/IN is the secondary hub: Midwest research, agricultural operations, lower cost base. Both regions target 50-200 acres at below-market prices.
comments.Protocol-PropertyScoring: Eight-dimension weighted scoring heuristic for evaluating candidate properties. Each dimension scored 1-10, then multiplied by its weight. Final score is the weighted sum. Hard filters eliminate properties before scoring begins.
comments.CandidateProperty: A real property evaluated as a potential OASIS campus site. Scored by Protocol-PropertyScoring across 8 dimensions. Each candidate has location, acreage, price, score, and tier.

files.purpose: The three-entity recursive engine: SumAI  SomeAI  Serengeti.

comments.ResearchOrganization: A divergent engine  an entity whose purpose is to widen the research frontier. SumAI is the only current instance. Research organizations produce discoveries and consume funding.
comments.DeploymentOrganization: A convergent engine  an entity that takes research outputs and deploys them into client operations. SomeAI is the only current instance. Deployment organizations produce revenue and consume discoveries.
comments.PrivateEquityCatalyst: A capital entity that funds the research-deployment loop. Serengeti is the only current instance. PE catalysts produce funding and consume revenue returns.
comments.SharedSubstrate: Infrastructure shared across all entities in the loop. Charlotte OS is the shared substrate  the graph that SumAI researches on, SomeAI deploys through, and Serengeti monitors for returns.
comments.fundsResearch: (fundsResearch Serengeti SumAI)  capital flows from PE catalyst to research organization. Funds lab operations, campus acquisition, researcher salaries.
comments.discoveryFlow: (discoveryFlow SumAI SomeAI)  research discoveries flow from the divergent engine to the convergent engine for deployment.
comments.fieldDataFlow: (fieldDataFlow SomeAI SumAI)  real-world operational signals from client deployments flow back to the research lab as training data and research problems.
comments.revenueReturn: (revenueReturn SomeAI Serengeti)  deployment revenue returns to the PE catalyst, fueling the next cycle of investment.
comments.runsOnSubstrate: (runsOnSubstrate SumAI CharlotteOS)  this entity operates on the shared substrate. Charlotte is the common infrastructure.
comments.TeamRole: The pride model: Imagineers are the hunters, Mentors are the experienced pride members who teach hunting patterns, Advisors are the territorial anchors. Everyone benefits from the collective knowledge density. The Serengeti metaphor made literal.
comments.Imagineer: Active scientists and engineers in their late 20s to early 30s. Each leads research in one of the six pillars. They are the hunters  the people doing the frontier work.
comments.Mentor: Industry veterans in their 40s to 80s, paired 1-to-many with Imagineers. Neuro and heart surgeons, experimental chefs, professors. They keep the Imagineers on the frontier by providing decades of domain expertise, pattern recognition, and access to problems worth solving.
comments.Advisor: Industry leaders who advise on strategic direction. Not necessarily mentoring individuals but steering the research agenda. Territorial anchors who define where the pride operates.
comments.PathToHexCampus: The two routes to realizing the OASIS research campus.
comments.Protocol-InnovationCycle: The fundamental protocol governing the SumAI-SomeAI duality. SumAI pushes the frontier outward (divergent). SomeAI pulls deployable solutions inward (convergent). Innovation pumped constantly into the industries we touch. Neither engine works without the other. Research without deployment is academic. Deployment without research is stagnation.
comments.Protocol-GenerationalFlywheel: Serengeti's generational recycling protocol. Mentors and engineers retire into Serengeti. Their capital and networks fund the next generation of Imagineers. The cycle repeats across generations. Jim Richard + Andrew Homoly are current-generation Serengeti anchors. Their children (Jack Richard, Mason Homoly) are current-generation Imagineers. The dead teach the living  literally.
comments.clientConsumes: (clientConsumes ISGParent CharlotteOS)  a client operates on Charlotte. Each client's deployment generates field data that flows back to SumAI.
comments.SomeAIClosedLoopMt: The business model is recursive: SomeAI ships Charlotte  clients embed it  each client consumes its industry  the graph IS the industry. Two paths to hex campus: enough clients  self-sustaining, OR enough traction  PE funding. Serengeti funds  SumAI researches  SomeAI deploys  revenue returns  cycle repeats.

files.purpose: The root boilerplate KRF that powers SomeAI's client onboarding

comments.OperatingCompany: A company that operates  SomeAI, client companies, etc.
comments.ClientRelationship: The top-level concept  a game Charlotte facilitates. A ClientRelationship is both a NODE (it has identity, lifecycle, attributes) and a PROTOCOL (it has phases, triggers, expected signals). When SomeAI says 'I want this client,' a ClientRelationship NODE is instantiated and the onboarding protocol begins executing. The relationship persists beyond onboarding  it is the permanent graph entity for this business partnership.
comments.ClientLifecycleState: The lifecycle states a client relationship passes through. These map to pipeline stages but carry semantic weight  a ProspectiveClient generates different signals than an ActiveClient.
comments.ProspectiveClient: A business SomeAI has identified and is actively pursuing. The onboarding engine is running. Deliverables are being generated. No contract is signed yet. This is the state where Charlotte does the most work  every phase from INTAKE through PRESENTATION executes while the client is prospective.
comments.ActiveClient: A business with a signed MSA. The double contract is live. Charlotte is deployed into their operations. Monthly retainer is flowing. Signals shift from onboarding signals to operational signals  engagement, performance, renewal risk.
comments.PartnerOrganization: An industry body in a revenue-sharing partnership, not a direct managed-service client. NSR, CPS, TSA are partners  they deploy through Sounder, not through a direct SomeAI MSA. Partner relationships have different economics but the same onboarding intelligence requirements.
comments.ChurnedClient: A client whose contract expired or was terminated without renewal. Charlotte retains the relationship graph  churned clients are dormant NODEs, not deleted ones. Reactivation protocol can fire if new engagement signals appear.
comments.DormantProspect: A prospect where the onboarding engine stalled. No engagement signals for 60+ days. Charlotte stops generating deliverables but keeps the relationship NODE warm. Any new signal reactivates the protocol from the phase where it stalled.
comments.IndustryVertical: The competitive space a client operates in. Industry verticals carry template intelligence  pre-built patterns for competitive analysis, migration paths, and pricing. Charlotte's cross-domain thesis means every new vertical enriches the platform. A vertical with no existing Charlotte deployment is a greenfield opportunity.
comments.Deliverable: Any document or artifact SomeAI produces during the onboarding process. Deliverables are NODEs because they have identity, creation timestamps, version history, and quality state. Each deliverable is produced by a specific protocol phase and has defined inputs, output format, and quality gates.
comments.DeliverableType: The category of a deliverable  pitch deck, brand book, MSA, etc. DeliverableTypes carry template intelligence: what inputs are needed, what format the output takes, what quality gates must pass.
comments.MigrationPath: A possible deployment strategy for getting Charlotte into a client's operations. Every client gets three options: full ecosystem ingestion, targeted domain deployment, or pilot proof-of-concept. The migration path chosen determines the Foundation Phase contract scope, timeline, and cost.
comments.ContractTemplate: The double-contract structure that every SomeAI client signs. Contract A is deployment and migration (one-time, scope-based). Contract B is ongoing managed service (monthly, tiered, 2-year lock). The template carries pricing rules, clause structures, and auto-renewal terms. ISG's contracts are the master template.
comments.CompetitiveEntity: A competitor in a client's industry vertical. Charlotte maps the competitive landscape during RECONNAISSANCE to identify data strategy gaps  if no competitor has a data strategy, the client is in a greenfield vertical and the deal probability escalates.
comments.ClientOnboardingProtocol: The master onboarding protocol. Seven phases from INTAKE to PRESENTATION. This protocol fires when initiateRelationship is asserted for a ProspectiveClient. It orchestrates all deliverable generation, competitive analysis, brand identity, migration planning, contract drafting, and pitch assembly. Every SomeAI client passes through this protocol. ISG was instance zero.
comments.OnboardingPhase: A discrete phase in the onboarding protocol. Each phase has a phase number, required input signals, produced deliverables, dependency edges, and completion criteria. Charlotte tracks phase state  not-started, in-progress, blocked, complete.
comments.PhaseState: Execution state of a protocol phase.
comments.Phase-Intake: Trigger: 'I want this client.' Charlotte begins data gathering. This is the seed phase  it requires the minimum viable signal set to instantiate a ClientRelationship NODE. No dependencies. Output: initial assessment document with company profile, industry classification, and preliminary opportunity score.
comments.Phase-Reconnaissance: Charlotte scans the client's industry vertical. Competitive analysis maps every significant player. Market position is established. Data strategy gaps are identified  the absence of data intelligence in a vertical is the strongest buy signal. Depends on: Phase-Intake (need company identity and industry). Output: competitive landscape document with market map.
comments.Phase-Theming: Brand identity generation. Three possible design directions based on industry vertical and competitive space. Color palettes, typography, visual identity, and GeoParticle identity art. The brand book is both a deliverable and a credibility signal  it tells the client 'we already see you.' Depends on: Phase-Reconnaissance (competitive space informs design). Output: brand book options (3 directions).
comments.Phase-MigrationAnalysis: Three deployment paths presented to the client: Path A (Full Ecosystem Ingestion)  highest value, longest timeline. Path B (Targeted Domain Deployment)  mid value, mid timeline. Path C (Pilot Proof-of-Concept)  lowest barrier, fastest. Each path specifies scope, timeline, cost range, and risk factors. Depends on: Phase-Intake (need tech stack signals) and Phase-Reconnaissance (need competitive context for scoping). Output: migration options document with 3 paths.
comments.Phase-Valuation: Cost modeling and ROI projection. Deployment contract pricing is calculated from the chosen migration path. Ongoing service pricing is tiered ($20K-$80K/mo based on complexity and value). 2-year projected value is computed for the client's CFO. The valuation phase converts technical scoping into dollar amounts. Depends on: Phase-MigrationAnalysis (need path selection for pricing). Output: pricing/ROI document.
comments.Phase-DeliverableGeneration: All client-facing documents assembled into the complete package. This is the integration phase  everything produced in phases 0-4 is compiled, refined, and formatted for delivery. The pitch deck gets its before/after Charlotte visualization. The PRD captures their Charlotte deployment spec. The MSA and SOW become signable. Depends on: All previous phases. Output: complete client package.
comments.Phase-Presentation: The pitch meeting. Live demo of Charlotte applied to their data. Before/after visualization on screen. Contract on the table. This phase has no deliverable output  its output is a signed contract and a state transition from ProspectiveClient to ActiveClient. Depends on: Phase-DeliverableGeneration (all documents ready). Output: signed contract (state transition).
comments.IntakeSignal: Initial data about a prospect. The minimum viable signal set for instantiating a ClientRelationship: company name, industry vertical, revenue estimate, employee count, key contacts, existing tech stack, and geographic location. Charlotte cannot begin without these. An IntakeSignal with missing fields is flagged as incomplete and the protocol blocks until the gaps are filled.
comments.CompetitiveSignal: Market intelligence about the client's competitive landscape. Competitor names, market positions, technology stacks, data strategy presence or absence, market share estimates, and funding status. Charlotte uses competitive signals to map the industry vertical and identify the data strategy vacuum that SomeAI fills.
comments.EngagementSignal: Any interaction between SomeAI and the prospect  meeting notes, emails, phone calls, site visits, demo sessions. Engagement signals carry sentiment (positive, neutral, negative), participant list, duration, and key takeaways. The frequency and sentiment of engagement signals directly feed the RelationshipHealth metric and DealProbability metric.
comments.TechnicalSignal: Information about the client's existing technology infrastructure. Current software systems, data formats, database types, API availability, integration complexity, data volume estimates, and IT staffing. Technical signals determine migration path options and DeploymentComplexity scoring.
comments.FinancialSignal: Revenue data, budget information, pricing sensitivity indicators, and investment capacity. Financial signals drive tier assignment and contract value calculation. A company with $450M revenue gets different pricing than one with $2.2M  Charlotte adjusts the tier recommendation automatically.
comments.RelationshipHealth: Engagement score across all interactions. Computed from engagement signal frequency, sentiment distribution, response latency, and meeting attendance. Range: 0-100. Above 70 indicates active engagement. Below 30 triggers the dormancy protocol. This is the pulse metric  if RelationshipHealth flatlines, the deal is dying.
comments.DealProbability: Likelihood of closing the contract, expressed as a percentage. Derived from: RelationshipHealth, competitive landscape (greenfield = higher probability), client revenue (higher = more complex but more valuable), engagement signal trajectory (improving or declining), and phase completion rate. DealProbability above 60% triggers accelerated deliverable generation.
comments.DeploymentComplexity: Technical difficulty estimate for Charlotte deployment, on a 1-10 scale. Computed from: number of existing systems to integrate, data format heterogeneity, API availability, data volume, IT staff sophistication, and legacy system age. Higher complexity means higher Foundation Phase pricing but also higher lock-in value. Complexity 1-3: pilot-ready. 4-6: targeted deployment. 7-10: full ecosystem ingestion.
comments.RevenueProjection: Expected total contract value over the 2-year engagement. Computed from: service tier assignment, migration path selection, Foundation Phase scope estimate, and auto-renewal probability. This is the number that matters to SomeAI's revenue forecast  it feeds directly into the ProjectedARR calculations in business_model.krf.
comments.TimeToClose: Estimated calendar days from first IntakeSignal to signed contract. Derived from: industry vertical template (some industries move faster), engagement signal velocity, decision-maker access, competitive pressure, and phase completion rate. Average across existing pipeline: 45-90 days. ISG template: 60 days.
comments.hasProspect: (hasProspect SomeAI ?rel)  SomeAI is actively pursuing this client relationship. The edge that connects SomeAI to every active onboarding game in the graph.
comments.hasLifecycleState: (hasLifecycleState ?rel ProspectiveClient)  the current lifecycle state of the client relationship. Transitions are governed by protocol phase completion.
comments.inVertical: (inVertical ?rel IndustrialService)  the industry vertical this client operates in. Determines which vertical template Charlotte loads for competitive analysis and migration planning.
comments.competsWith: (competsWith ?rel ?competitor)  this client competes with this entity. Charlotte maps the competitive graph during RECONNAISSANCE to understand market position and identify data strategy gaps.
comments.requiresDeliverable: (requiresDeliverable Phase-Valuation PricingROI)  this phase requires this deliverable type as input from a prior phase.
comments.producesDeliverableType: (producesDeliverableType Phase-Theming BrandBook)  this phase produces this deliverable type as output.
comments.dependsOn: (dependsOn Phase-Theming Phase-Reconnaissance)  this phase cannot begin until the dependency phase is complete. Charlotte enforces ordering through dependency edges  parallel execution is permitted only where no dependency exists.
comments.hasMigrationPath: (hasMigrationPath ?rel PathA-FullIngestion)  this client has this migration path as a deployment option. Every client gets three paths; the client selects one during Phase-Valuation.
comments.hasContractTemplate: (hasContractTemplate ?rel DoubleContractTemplate)  the contract structure assigned to this client relationship.
comments.hasPhaseState: (hasPhaseState ?rel Phase-Intake PhaseComplete)  the execution state of a specific phase for a specific client relationship.
comments.assignedTier: (assignedTier ?rel Tier2-ActiveManagement)  the ongoing service tier assigned to this client based on financial and complexity signals.
comments.selectedPath: (selectedPath ?rel PathB-TargetedDomain)  the migration path the client selected from the three options presented.
comments.DoubleContractTemplate: The master template. Every SomeAI managed-service client signs two contracts simultaneously: Contract A (Foundation): Deployment and migration. One-time fee. Scope-based pricing derived from the selected migration path. Contract B (Operations): Ongoing managed service. Monthly retainer. Tiered pricing. 2-year lock-in with auto-renewal. ISG is the template instance: Foundation ~$150K-$300K, Operations $40K/mo ($960K/2yr).
comments.FoundationContract: Contract A: Deployment & migration. One-time, scope-based. Pricing derived from migration path: Path A (Full Ingestion): $150K-$500K, 4-8 months. Path B (Targeted Domain): $75K-$200K, 2-4 months. Path C (Pilot/POC): $25K-$75K, 4-8 weeks. Includes: discovery, vocabulary config, historical import, graph seeding, protocol calibration, validation & handoff.
comments.OperationsContract: Contract B: Ongoing managed service. Monthly retainer. 2-year lock. Three tiers based on engagement depth and client value.
comments.ServiceTier: The ongoing service tier determines the monthly retainer, the scope of Charlotte's active management, and the cadence of human review. Tier assignment is driven by client revenue, deployment complexity, and selected migration path.
comments.Tier1-Monitoring: Tier 1: $20,000/mo. Charlotte monitors and reports. Quarterly human reviews. Automated signal processing and metric tracking. Alert-based intervention only. Best for: small operations with straightforward deployments, post-pilot expansions, and clients who want observability without active optimization. 2-year value: $480,000.
comments.Tier2-ActiveManagement: Tier 2: $40,000/mo. Charlotte actively manages and optimizes. Monthly optimization cycles. Proactive protocol tuning. Dedicated Charlotte analyst. Best for: mid-size operations with moderate complexity, clients generating actionable signal volume, and businesses ready for Charlotte-driven decision support. ISG is a Tier 2 client. 2-year value: $960,000.
comments.Tier3-EmbeddedTeam: Tier 3: $80,000/mo. Embedded SomeAI team on-site or dedicated. Continuous development of new Charlotte protocols. Weekly strategy sessions. Custom deliverable generation. Best for: PE portfolio companies, high-revenue multi-brand operations, and clients where Charlotte is the central operating intelligence. 2-year value: $1,920,000.
comments.ContractClause: A standard clause in the SomeAI MSA.
comments.LockInClause: 2-year minimum commitment. The client cannot terminate the Operations contract before 24 months without paying the remaining balance. This is non-negotiable  it ensures SomeAI has the runway to deliver full value and amortize Foundation costs.
comments.AutoRenewalClause: Automatic renewal at the end of the 2-year term unless either party provides 90-day written notice. Renewal rate: current tier rate plus up to 5% annual adjustment. The default state is continuity  the client must actively choose to leave.
comments.DataOwnershipClause: The client owns their data. SomeAI owns the Charlotte substrate, protocols, and inference rules. The KRF knowledge base built during deployment is jointly owned  the client gets a full export on termination, but the structural patterns and protocol templates remain SomeAI intellectual property.
comments.IPClause: Charlotte OS, all primitives, substrate architecture, and cross-domain intelligence remain SomeAI property. Client-specific configurations are work-for-hire owned by the client. The platform itself  the thing that makes it all work  never transfers.
comments.PathA-FullIngestion: Full Ecosystem Ingestion. Charlotte absorbs the client's entire operational data universe  every system, every database, every spreadsheet, every tribal knowledge artifact. The result is a complete digital twin of the business in Charlotte's substrate. Scope: All systems, all data, all processes. Timeline: 4-8 months. Cost: $150,000-$500,000. Risk: Longest timeline, highest discovery risk, most stakeholders. Value: Maximum lock-in, deepest intelligence, hardest to replace. Best for: PE portfolio companies, multi-brand operations, ISG-class.
comments.PathB-TargetedDomain: Targeted Domain Deployment. Charlotte deploys into a single high-value operational domain  the one where the client feels the most pain. Equipment tracking, crew management, inventory, pedigree, whatever the critical gap is. Proves value in one domain, then expands. Scope: One operational domain, 2-4 data sources. Timeline: 2-4 months. Cost: $75,000-$200,000. Risk: Moderate  limited scope reduces discovery risk. Value: Fast proof of value, natural expansion path. Best for: Mid-size companies, cautious decision-makers, first-time buyers.
comments.PathC-Pilot: Pilot Proof-of-Concept. Charlotte deploys on a single dataset or process  typically the client's most painful manual workflow. The pilot is designed to produce a visceral before/after moment in under 8 weeks. If the pilot succeeds, the client upgrades to Path B or A. Scope: One dataset or process, minimal integration. Timeline: 4-8 weeks. Cost: $25,000-$75,000. Risk: Low  contained scope, fast feedback loop. Value: Lowest barrier to entry, fastest time-to-value. Best for: Skeptics, budget-constrained, small operations, All State-class.
comments.InitialAssessment: Company profile + opportunity score. Phase 0 output.
comments.CompetitiveLandscape: Market map + competitive analysis. Phase 1 output.
comments.BrandBook: Visual identity with 3 design directions. Phase 2 output.
comments.MigrationOptions: 3 deployment paths with scope/timeline/cost. Phase 3 output.
comments.PricingROI: Contract pricing + ROI projection. Phase 4 output.
comments.PitchDeck: Before/after Charlotte visualization + full pitch. Phase 5 output.
comments.PRD: Product requirements for their Charlotte deployment. Phase 5 output.
comments.MSA: Master Service Agreement  the double contract. Phase 5 output.
comments.SOW: Statement of work for the Foundation Phase deployment. Phase 5 output.
comments.Roadmap: Implementation timeline spanning Foundation into Operations. Phase 5 output.
comments.VerticalTemplate: A pre-built intelligence pattern for an industry vertical. Templates encode what Charlotte has learned from prior engagements in this space. A template with a completed deployment (like ISG for industrial services) carries higher confidence than a greenfield template.
comments.hasVerticalTemplate: (hasVerticalTemplate IndustrialService ISGTemplate)  this vertical has this pre-built template available for new prospects.
comments.IndustrialServicesTemplate: ISG template. PE-backed industrial service. Multi-brand portfolio. Typical competitors: Comfort Systems USA, APi Group, EMCOR, Lennox. Common data gap: Cross-brand visibility. Siloed CRMs per acquisition. Expected complexity: 7-9. Recommended tier: Tier 2 or Tier 3. Narrative reference: ISGNarrative. Confidence: HIGH  deployed and live.
comments.ManufacturingTemplate: All State template. Small manufacturing, sub-$5M. Metal fixtures. Typical competitors: Lozier, Madix, Handy Store Fixtures. Common data gap: Zero digital presence. Tribal knowledge only. Expected complexity: 2-4. Recommended tier: Tier 1. Narrative reference: AllStateNarrative. Confidence: MEDIUM  onboarding package drafted, not deployed.
comments.LogisticsTemplate: Top Tier template. Distributed crew operations. Interstate moving. Typical competitors: Two Men and a Truck, United Van Lines, PODS. Common data gap: No crew-level performance tracking. Collection leak. Expected complexity: 4-6. Recommended tier: Tier 1 or Tier 2. Narrative reference: TopTierNarrative. Confidence: MEDIUM  data analyzed, not deployed.
comments.AgricultureTemplate: Sounder template. Livestock genetics, pedigree registration. Typical competitors: DigitalBeef, Valley Ag, no direct swine equivalent. Common data gap: No crossbred tracking. Registries siloed by breed. Expected complexity: 6-8. Recommended tier: Partner (revenue share). Narrative reference: SounderNarrative. Confidence: HIGH  401K facts, deepest Charlotte deployment.
comments.CollectiblesTemplate: CardVault template. Premium retail, multi-location. Sports cards. Typical competitors: PWCC, eBay, Goldin Auctions. Common data gap: No cross-store CRM. Separate Shopify instances. Expected complexity: 5-7. Recommended tier: Tier 2. Narrative reference: CardVaultNarrative. Confidence: MEDIUM  assessment complete, not deployed.
comments.EcommerceAuctionTemplate: SC Online Sales template. Multi-species livestock auctions. Typical competitors: LiveAuctions.tv, Cattle Range, DV Auction. Common data gap: No cross-species buyer intelligence. Expected complexity: 5-7. Recommended tier: Tier 2. Narrative reference: SCOnlineSalesNarrative. Confidence: MEDIUM  assessment complete, not deployed.
comments.GeneticsIntelligenceTemplate: Wendt Group template. Show livestock auction + genetics intelligence. Typical competitors: None with pedigree graph capability. Common data gap: Crossbred animals completely untracked. Expected complexity: 6-8. Recommended tier: Tier 2. Narrative reference: WendtGroupNarrative. Confidence: MEDIUM  deep domain knowledge via Sounder.
comments.GreenfieldTemplate: Generic template for unknown or new industry verticals. No prior Charlotte deployment in this space. RECONNAISSANCE phase runs the full discovery protocol without template acceleration. Expected complexity: Unknown  defaults to 5 pending assessment. Recommended tier: Unknown  determined by Phase 4 VALUATION. Confidence: LOW  no prior intelligence.
comments.phaseNumber: (phaseNumber ?phase ?n)  ordinal position of the phase. 0=INTAKE through 6=PRESENTATION.
comments.requiresSignalType: (requiresSignalType ?phase ?signalType)  this phase needs signals of this type to execute.
comments.deliverableFormat: (deliverableFormat ?type ?format)  the output format for this deliverable.
comments.deliverableInputs: (deliverableInputs ?type ?inputs)  what data Charlotte needs to generate this deliverable.
comments.deliverableQualityGate: (deliverableQualityGate ?type ?criteria)  what must be verified before this deliverable ships.
comments.tierMonthlyRate: (tierMonthlyRate ?tier ?dollars)  monthly retainer for this service tier.
comments.templateDeploymentCount: (templateDeploymentCount ?template ?n)  number of completed deployments using this template.
comments.templateRecommendedTier: (templateRecommendedTier ?template ?tier)  default tier recommendation for this vertical.
comments.initiateRelationship: (initiateRelationship SomeAI ?client)  the trigger assertion that starts the onboarding engine.
comments.beginProtocol: (beginProtocol ClientOnboardingProtocol ?client)  activates the protocol for the given client.
comments.recommendedTier: (recommendedTier ?rel ?tier)  Charlotte's tier recommendation based on financial and complexity signals.
comments.recommendedPath: (recommendedPath ?rel ?path)  Charlotte's migration path recommendation based on complexity assessment.
comments.isGreenfieldOpportunity: (isGreenfieldOpportunity ?rel true)  no competitor in this vertical has a data strategy.
comments.escalateDealProbability: (escalateDealProbability ?rel ?points)  increase DealProbability metric by this amount.
comments.accelerateDeliverables: (accelerateDeliverables ?rel true)  fast-track deliverable generation for high-probability deals.
comments.transitionState: (transitionState ?rel ActiveClient)  move the relationship to a new lifecycle state.
comments.loadTemplate: (loadTemplate ?rel ?template)  load the vertical template intelligence into this relationship's RECONNAISSANCE phase.
comments.contractSigned: (contractSigned ?rel FoundationContract)  the client has signed this contract.
comments.canAdvanceTo: (canAdvanceTo ?rel Phase-Theming)  all dependencies met, phase is eligible to begin.
comments.generateAssessment: (generateAssessment ?rel MigrationComplexityAssessment)  trigger a specific assessment generation.
comments.hasSignalOfType: (hasSignalOfType ?rel TechnicalSignal)  this relationship has received at least one signal of this type.
comments.daysSinceLastSignal: (daysSinceLastSignal ?rel EngagementSignal ?days)  calendar days since the most recent signal of this type.
comments.receivedSignal: (receivedSignal ?rel ?signal)  a new signal has arrived on this relationship.
comments.hasDataStrategy: (hasDataStrategy ?competitor true)  this competitor has an observable data/intelligence strategy.

files.purpose: The OASIS research campus  Central Place Theory hexagonal

comments.CampusZone: A hex cell in the OASIS campus. Central Place Theory (Christaller, 1933) states hexagonal tessellation maximizes accessibility, minimizes travel distance, and creates natural hierarchies of specialization.
comments.hexCoord: (hexCoord ZoneServerCore 0 0)  axial hex coordinates (q, r). Pointy-top hexes. Used for adjacency computation.
comments.adjacentZone: (adjacentZone ZoneServerCore ZoneSightLab)  these zones share a hex edge.
comments.zonePillar: (zonePillar ZoneSightLab PillarSight)  this zone serves this pillar.
comments.SumAIOASISCampusMt: Central Place Theory: the server core sits at the geographic center. Six pillar labs surround it at equal distance. Shared facilities fill the interstitial hexes. Every point on campus is within 2 hex-steps of the core and 1 hex-step of a pillar lab. The property is designed so Charlotte can observe the entire campus as a living substrate  every building, every room, every researcher is a NODE emitting SIGNALs.

files.purpose: Core identity, six sensory pillars, progression levels,

comments.SensoryPillar: One of six research pillars organized around human senses. The senses are the universal interface between reality and observation. Charlotte is the infrastructure for observable reality. SumAI studies the senses. The connection is structural, not metaphorical.
comments.hasPillarDomain: (hasPillarDomain PillarSight ?domain)  the research domain this pillar covers.
comments.hasPillarApplications: (hasPillarApplications PillarSight ?apps)  real-world applications of this pillar.
comments.hasPillarColor: (hasPillarColor PillarSight ?hex)  brand color for this pillar.
comments.PillarBrain: The Brain pillar maintains Charlotte itself  the infrastructure for observable reality that makes all other pillars possible.
comments.ProgressionLevel: Depth within a single sensory pillar. Every researcher enters the OASIS at Level I of their primary sense.
comments.hasLevelNumber: (hasLevelNumber LevelI 1)  ordinal position of the level.
comments.hasLevelYearRange: (hasLevelYearRange LevelI 1 2)  typical year range for this level.
comments.LevelI-Fundamentals: Sensing, signal acquisition, basic AI models.
comments.LevelIII-Expert: Novel research, pushing the frontier of that sense.
comments.LevelV-Architect: Designing the infrastructure that future researchers build on. Full multimodal integration or deep single-sense mastery.
comments.Protocol-EightYearRotation: A hypothetical full rotation through the OASIS: Years 1-2: Primary sense Level I-II  foundational mastery. Years 2-3: Primary sense Level III + first cross-sensory  expert + breadth. Years 3-5: Two-sense combinations, primary to Level IV  novel cross-modal research. Years 5-7: Three-sense combinations, mentoring new Level I  pioneer status. Years 7-8: Four/five-sense integration or deep specialization (Level V)  architect or full multimodal. Researchers can also choose to specialize  staying in Smell I through Smell V without branching, becoming the world's deepest expert in olfactory AI. Both paths are valued. The hexagonal layout supports both breadth and depth naturally.
comments.CrossSensoryResearch: Research at the intersection of two or more sensory pillars. These are the boundary zones in the hexagonal layout where cross-pillar research happens.
comments.involvesPillar: (involvesPillar CrossSight-Touch PillarSight)  this cross-sensory research involves this pillar.
comments.CrossSight-Touch: Surgical robotics, haptic feedback from visual input.
comments.CrossSight-Taste: Visual food quality assessment, plating science.
comments.CrossSight-Smell: Crop health imaging + VOC detection, disease screening.
comments.CrossTouch-Smell: Soil quality + plant VOC sensing, agricultural diagnostics.

comments.CrossSight-Touch-Smell: Agricultural digital twin  crop imaging + soil + VOC.
comments.CrossSight-Sound-Taste: Dining experience design  plating + ambience + flavor.
comments.CrossSight-Taste-Smell: Sensory food science  visual + flavor + aroma.
comments.CrossTouch-Sound-Taste: Texture + sonic + flavor  multisensory food research.
comments.CrossTouch-Taste-Smell: Full culinary science stack  the Enigma connection.
comments.CrossAllFiveSenses: The most difficult implementation. Years of combined research to unlock. Full multimodal AI  Charlotte observing reality through all channels simultaneously. The innermost ring around Brain.
comments.DeploymentVertical: A real-world domain where SumAI research converges into SomeAI deployments. Each vertical is a convergent application of research that started as divergent exploration in the OASIS.
comments.primarySense: (primarySense VerticalAgriTech PillarSight)  primary sensory pillar for this vertical.
comments.Protocol-InnovationCycle-Detail: The detailed flow: 1. SumAI discovers (divergent exploration in the OASIS). 2. Discoveries flow to SomeAI via discoveryFlow. 3. SomeAI deploys into client operations (ISG, Sounder, etc.). 4. Deployments generate real-world signals (field data). 5. Field data flows back to SumAI via fieldDataFlow. 6. SumAI refines research based on real problems. 7. Charlotte is the substrate both engines run on. 8. The Brain pillar maintains Charlotte itself. Cycle repeats. The question is never 'what can Charlotte do?' The question is 'what can Charlotte observe?'
comments.SumAI: First articulated February 14, 2026. The OASIS exists in concept. The people are real. The research is underway.

files.purpose: The five irreducible primitives of Charlotte

comments.NODE: Identity. Any uniquely identifiable entity in the graph.
comments.EDGE: Relationship. A typed, directed connection between two NODEs.
comments.METRIC: Quantitative signal. A measurable dimension attached to a NODE.
comments.SIGNAL: Event. A timestamped observation placed on a METRIC line.
comments.PROTOCOL: Rule. Business logic that governs graph evolution.
comments.FACT: The atomic unit of knowledge in Charlotte. Every piece of information is a FACT.

files.purpose: Core type system  collections, predicates, and constraints

comments.StructuralKnowledge: Relationship between object and concept. The web of typed edges.
comments.DeclarativeKnowledge: Object facts. Assertions that are true or false.
comments.ProceduralKnowledge: Rules and procedures. How to do things.
comments.HeuristicKnowledge: Rules of thumb. Approximate reasoning from observation.
comments.MetaKnowledge: Knowledge about knowledge. Self-awareness of the system.
comments.:ID: Unique identifier. Immutable. Set at FACT creation.
comments.:TYPE: Primitive type. One of NODE, EDGE, METRIC, SIGNAL, PROTOCOL.
comments.P0: Payload register 0. Type-specific. See primitive definition.

files.purpose: The serial reasoning architecture that distinguishes Charlotte

comments.ValuationLayer: The serial reasoning pipeline (METRIC  SIGNAL  PROTOCOL) that sits on top of the ontological graph (NODE + EDGE). The valuation layer is not traversed ambiguously  it is processed serially, like a signal processing pipeline. Every conclusion has a deterministic, traceable reasoning path back through the exact signals and metrics that produced it.
comments.OntologicalLayer: The structural knowledge graph (NODE + EDGE). Answers 'what exists' and 'how things relate.' Supports standard graph traversal and topological reasoning. This is the layer most KG implementations stop at.
comments.DiveLineProperty: Every conclusion in the valuation layer has a complete, serial, deterministic trace back to the raw metrics and graph entities that produced it. This trace is the dive line. It is never probabilistic. It is never approximate. It is the line.
comments.ObserverPerspective: The valuation layer is perspectival  it encodes the observer's judgment, not objective truth. Two observers looking at the same NODE+EDGE graph may place different SIGNALs on the same METRICs because they apply different thresholds and different PROTOCOLs. This is by design. The graph (facts) is shared. The valuation (interpretation) is scoped to the observer's microtheory.
comments.valuationChain: (valuationChain ?protocol ?signal ?metric ?node) The complete dive line from a protocol firing back to the entity it concerns. Every protocol must have at least one complete chain. If you cannot produce the chain, the protocol has no grounding and should not fire.
